findings.title: Use unchecked math to block overflow / underflow check to save Gas
findings.description: Unchecked math operations can cause overflow or underflow, which is blocked to save gas.

findings.title: I14. Unpacked Variables Consuming Gas
findings.description: Unnecessary gas consumption and code clutter due to unpacked variables.

findings.title: L05. Front-Running; Pricing Manipulation in Fixed Sale
findings.description: In fixed-sale contracts, sellers can modify prices at their discretion, allowing them to frontrun buyers and cause them to pay more than the initially expected price.

findings.title: Ownership Irrevocability Vulnerability in Smart Contract
findings.description: The smart contract inherits from the Ownable library, which provides basic authorization control functions. However, once the owner renounces ownership using the renounceOwnership function, the contract becomes ownerless and attempts to call functions that require owner permissions fail.

findings.title: Avoid Unnecessary Initializations Of Uint256 And Bool Variable To 0/false
findings.description: Unnecessary initialization of uint256 and bool variables to 0 or false respectively adds verbosity to the code, may make it less readable, and increases Gas costs without providing any functional benefit.

findings.title: I03. Custom Errors For Better Gas Efficiency
findings.description: Using custom errors instead of revert strings can significantly reduce gas costs, especially when deploying contracts.

findings.title: I04. Revert String Size
findings.description: Including long revert strings can be expensive in terms of Gas usage. By shortening the revert strings to fit within 32 bytes, we can reduce the amount of Gas used during deployment and runtime when the revert condition is met.

findings.title: Immutable Keyword For Gas Optimization
findings.description: Marking variables as immutable can greatly improve Gas costs if they do not change.

findings.title: I06. Missing Revert Messages In The require Statements
findings.description: The require function is used without a descriptive error message, resulting in less informative feedback to users or interacting contracts, which can pose challenges in debugging failed transactions.

findings.title: I07. `event` Declared But Not Emitted
findings.description: An event within the contract is declared but not utilized in any of the contract's functions or operations.

findings.title: I08. Avoid Using State Variables Directly In `emit`
findings.description: Avoid directly using state variables within the emit function when logging events to maintain gas efficiency and contract reliability.

findings.title: I09. Redundant Validation of Fee Setter
findings.description: The 'require' statement checking if feeSetter is not zero address is redundant since it's already checked by the onlyFeeSetter modifier.

findings.title: I10. Do Not Use totalSupply() In For Loop
findings.description: The totalSupply() function is called within a loop to determine the current supply repeatedly, leading to unnecessary gas consumption. It's recommended to cache its value before entering the loop.

findings.title: I11. Unfinalized Implementation
findings.description: The callNft function within the system lacks implementation and includes to-do comments, indicating that its existence is unclear and the code is evidently unfinished.
